text:
“Your humble servant, P. Luzhin,” the letter read.

Pulcheria Alexandrovna wept. “What do I do now, Dmitri?”

“Act on Avdotya’s decision,” Razumihin replied calmly.

“Oh, dear! She insists Rodya must be here at eight. He’ll come if he knows.”

Razumihin frowned. “He was strange yesterday. He mentioned a dead man and a girl.”

“Which cost you such sacrifice, mother,” Avdotya said quietly.

“I wanted to stop him from coming!” Pulcheria cried. “He’s so irritable.”

Razumihin sighed. “We must prepare for whatever happens.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Pulcheria Alexandrovna is distressed about how to handle Rodya's impending visit, fearing his reaction and the implications of a letter from Pyotr Petrovitch.
